sentences: Gil Shaham (Hebrew: גיל שחם; born February 19, 1971) is an American violinist of Israeli Jewish descent.
Gil Shaham was born in Urbana, Illinois, while his Israeli parents were on an academic fellowship at the University of Illinois.
Gil Shaham is a graduate of the Horace Mann School in New York.
When he was two the family moved to Jerusalem, where he started violin lessons at the Rubin Academy of Music aged seven, winning annual scholarships from the America-Israel Cultural Foundation.
He subsequently attended Aspen Music School in Colorado, studying with Dorothy DeLay and Jens Ellermann, and won a scholarship to the Juilliard School.
Shaham lives in New York City and teaches at Bard College Conservatory of Music.
He performed with the Israel Philharmonic, Israel's foremost orchestra, less than a year later.
Shaham's career advanced in 1989 when, while a senior at Horace Mann, he replaced an ailing Itzhak Perlman to perform the Bruch and Sibelius violin concertos with the London Symphony Orchestra.
Shaham won the Avery Fisher Career Grant in 1990, and the Premio Internazionale of the Accademia Chigiana in Siena in 1992.
Shaham has played the "Comtesse de Polignac", a Stradivarius violin of 1699 on loan from Stradivarius Society of Chicago, since 1989.
Mendelssohn, Bruch: Violin Concertos (with Giuseppe Sinopoli conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra)  (1990)
Schumann: Works for Violin and Piano (1990)
Franck / Saint-Saëns: Violin Sonatas (with Gerhard Oppitz) (1991)

1 and 2 (with Lawrence Foster conducting the London Symphony Orchestra) (1992)

1 and 2 (with Andre Previn conducting the London Symphony Orchestra) (1996)

Two Worlds (with Lee Ritenour and Dave Grusin) (2000)

Messiaen: Quartet for the End of Time (with Myung-Whun Chung) (2001)

Grammy Award for Best Chamber Music Performance: André Previn & Gil Shaham for American Scenes (Works of Copland, Previn, Barber, Gershwin) (1999)
Avery Fisher Award (2008) Presented by his dear friend Gustavo Dudamel at a Live from Lincoln Center private presentation of the music of Pablo de Sarasate in the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse.
